body.p: 6 important rules that must be adhered to in order to create a valid XML file:

rule.heading: Rule 1: XML Documents Must Have a Root Element
rule.body:
Every XML document must have a single root element that contains all other elements. This is the top-level element and defines the structure of the document. Code sample:
<root>...</root>

rule.heading: Rule 2: The XML Prolog
rule.body:
The XML prolog is optional but recommended. It provides important information like the XML version and character encoding used in the document. Code sample:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

rule.heading: Rule 3: All XML Elements Must Have a Closing Tag
rule.body:
Every opening XML tag must have a corresponding closing tag, or it should be self-closing. Code sample:
<element>Content</element>
Or:
<element />

rule.heading: Rule 4: XML Tags are Case Sensitive
rule.body:
XML tags are case-sensitive, meaning that <Tag> and <tag> are treated as different elements. Code sample:
<Example>This is different from <example></Example></example>

rule.heading: Rule 5: XML Elements Must be Properly Nested
rule.body: XML elements must be properly nested. For example, if you open a tag inside another tag, you must close the inner tag before closing the outer tag. Code sample: Content

rule.heading: Rule 6: XML Attribute Values Must Always be Quoted
rule.body:
In XML, attribute values must always be enclosed in quotation marks, either single or double. Code sample:
<element attribute="value">
